en.title: Ansible – Lesson 10: Conditionals & Loops
en.subtitle: Using when conditions and loops to control task execution in Ansible

sections.heading: 1. What are Conditionals in Ansible?
sections.content: Conditionals allow tasks to run only when a specific condition is true using the 'when' keyword.

sections.heading: 2. Why Use Conditionals?
sections.content: They help you run tasks based on OS type, variable values, command results or environment.

sections.heading: 3. Basic when Condition Example
sections.content: when: ansible_os_family == "Debian"

sections.heading: 4. Conditional with Variables
sections.content: when: app_port == 80

sections.heading: 5. Using Multiple Conditions
sections.content: You can combine conditions using and/or operators.

sections.heading: 6. What are Loops in Ansible?
sections.content: Loops allow you to repeat the same task multiple times with different values.

sections.heading: 7. Old Loop Method (with_items)
sections.content: with_items was the old way to loop over a list of items.

sections.heading: 8. New Loop Method (loop)
sections.content: The modern loop method uses the 'loop' keyword.

sections.heading: 9. Loop Example
sections.content: loop: - nginx - git - docker

sections.heading: 10. Using Loop with Variables
sections.content: You can loop through variable lists as well.

sections.heading: 11. Loop with Dictionaries
sections.content: Loops can also iterate over dictionaries using key-value pairs.

sections.heading: 12. Practical Use Case of Conditionals & Loops
sections.content: Install packages only on required OS and multiple software using a single task.

sections.heading: Lesson 10 Summary
sections.content: You learned how to control task execution using conditionals and repeat tasks using loops.
